text: researchers have created a semiconductor
paste that can be used to make solar
cells with little more than a paintbrush
office tape and a heat gun normally
solar cells are made in costly clean
rooms or other facilities that use
high-end equipment since this new
assembly method is so simple it could
pave the way for low-cost energy
harvesting devices first the researchers
prepare the paste which has four
well-known ingredients next they spread
the mixture onto the electrode and
anneal it with a heat gun finally they
sandwich an electrolyte solution between
the painted electrode and a graphene
composite electrode and then it's time
for testing under a beam of artificial
sunlight these cells are only 1%
efficient that's less than 1/10 of the
efficiency of a standard solar cell but
it's not bad for a first generation
device
